section.title: Hypothetical possibilities with if
section.sectiontitle: We use would/wouldn't + verb to talk about an imaginary/hypothetical situation. We usually use the short form when speaking.
section.text1: What would you do with a million dollars?
section.sectiontitle2: We use if + Past simple/Past continuous + would + verb to talk about a hypothetical situation or condition. This is often called the 'Second conditional'.
section.text3: We can start the with If and use a comma:
section.text3a: If I wasn't feeling so tired, I'd go for a walk.
section.text4: We can put if in the middle of the sentence:
section.text4a: I'd go for a walk if I wasn't feeling so tired.

section.title: Hypothetical possibilities with if
section.sectiontitle: We can use were or was in hypothetical if sentences. We often use If I were you … to give advice.
section.text1a: If Sam was here, he'd be angry.
section.text2a: I wouldn't trust him if I were you .
section.sectiontitle2: We can use might or could instead of would.
section.text3a: If you didn't talk so much, people might listen to you more.
section.text4a: I could help you if I had more time.
